Email 1:
Morning Vicente,                    I have 4,300MT of wheat from Odessa to Barcelona. Could you advise if you can fit this in early August, and what’s your standard demurrage clause?                    Best regards,                    Max
Email 2:
Dear Max,                      the answer is yes. Regarding demurrage terms, those are the standard FIOS terms (although please note that you do not mention your demurrage in your offer; it is customary to have the same clause both for buyer and seller). Please let me know whether you want me to send you a full contract asap.                     All the best,                      Vicente<Email 3>:
    Dear Vicente,                          thank you. I don’t require the full contract, just the demurrage clause would do. We will send you the draft offer in the next two days.                      Warm regards,                      Max<Email 4>:
    Dear Max,                          our offer would be based on the FIOS terms. Let me know if you accept and I’ll send you the draft offer asap.                      All the best,                      Vicente

Email 1:
Hello Yasir,                    Can you give a quick quote for transporting 18,700MT of fertilizers from Sohar to Jebel Ali with delivery before the 20th?                    Let me know if this cargo is a good fit and we can follow up with a booking.                    Best wishes,                    Zeinab
Email 2:
Jebel Ali Dry Cargo Team
Can you please send us your offer for the shipment of cargo and also attach your P&I certificate for us to consider.
Attachment:
Shipment/Forwarding/Cargo Confirmation: Yasir
Carrier: Kobe Kaiun
ETD: 17-18 Nov (Abu Dhabi)
ETA: 22 Nov (Jebel Ali)
Quantity: 18,700MT
Freight: U.S. $100,000.00
If you need any further information, please do not hesitate to contact me.
Email 3:
Hello Yasir,                                Can you send me a link to the P&I certificate? We want to make sure that this company is acceptable to our insurers.                                Best wishes,                                Zeinab
Attachment:
P&I Certificate for Cargo:
To whom it may concern:
This is to confirm that Kobe Kaiun is an acceptable carrier for Jebel Ali Dry Cargo Company. We issue this certificate of acceptance on behalf of the British Shipowners P&I Club. We advise our members that Kobe Kaiun is a safe and reliable carrier.
Best regards,
Oleg

<Email 4>:
Thanks for your P&I certificate. As I previously told you, this cargo is not a good fit for our company.
Best wishes,
Zeinab

Freight: U.S. $100

Email 1:
Hi Jose,                    My team and I are busy planning a 3,200MT shipment of palm kernels from Pointe Noire to Antwerp next month. If we need to load in a hurry, what kind of rates would you offer us?                    Regards,                    Karen
Email 2:
Jose,                    Glad we've touched base.                    I'd like to place a 1,600MT shipment of soya beans in January 2015 to deliver to Antwerp. I'd like to use your ship. Please send me a quote.                    Kind regards,                    Karen

Jose,
Thanks for the quotes! They're in line with our budget, but we'd like to speak to you directly about the details. Please call us at +1 555-555-5555
Warm regards,
Karen


<Email 3>:
Jose,
Great to hear from you! We'd like to book 1,600MT of soya beans on your ship to be delivered to Antwerp in the first week of March 2015. Are you able to provide a written quote?
Best,
Karen

We'd like to get a freight quote for 1,400mt of automotive steel plates from Houston to Antwerp. Our laycan is 12th September and can only handle minimum 2 days demurrage. Could you provide your best quote asap?                    Sincerely,                    Celia
Email 2:
I have received a freight quote from ocean freight broker for transport of 1,400 MT of steel from Houston to Antwerp, Belgium. If the quote is acceptable, we are prepared to sign the contract now, and the vessel can depart after October 7. The B/L will be drafted on our corporate FOB Rotterdam account.
Thank you and best regards,
Carl J.

How much will it cost to move 2,500 MT of refined sugar from Colombo to Amsterdam?                    Your shipping services team has to answer this type of question almost every day, so it’s important you can write shipping emails like a pro.                    To help you become a shipping emails expert, we’ve created this course. It covers the basics of shipping emails, including email design and structure. We’ve also included examples and tips to help you craft professional, error-free emails.                    Thanks for joining us for the “Become a Shipping Emails Expert” course. We hope you found the information helpful and useful.                    Enjoy the rest of your day,                    Brian

Email 1:
Hi Mr. Peter,                    We have a cargo to ship from Mundra to Long Beach. I do not anticipate any berth congestion in either port, but would you still please confirm that?                    Many thanks,                    Michael
Email 2:
Hi Michael,                  Hope you are well.                      As far as Mundra is concerned, there will be no berth congestion (whether it be monthly or weekly) in any month of this year.                 Regarding the port of Long Beach, the container volume is consistently increasing month on month. It will also increase in the coming month. However, we can see that in February 2019, there were 8 ETDs, whereas in January 2019 there were 7 ETDs. The transhipment movement from West Africa & other major US destinations to Long Beach will increase by more than 10% this year. Hence we may see less berth congestion in the months of January, February & March 2019. However, the probability of berth congestion in April and onward months is very high as long as the CBP do not relax any of their existing regulations to reduce the dwell

Kindly note the following changes in view of the proposed cut off 
· All STS, which were used in the past to eliminate congestion, will cease by end of March 2019. 
· Due to many more factors like larger volume, berth congestion & diversification, the terminal now prefers containers which are loaded on to wagons, trucks, rail heads, special containers (Transponders, Chilled, Refrigerated, etc.) as well as containers which are to be exported via Ocean Terminal, Pier 400, Long Beach Container Terminal (LBCT), ……………… the list goes on. 
· Longer term (year on year), terminal hopes that terminal will be able to achieve more in terms of more Gate out/container return, which is the only way the terminal will be able to handle more volume.

- Arrival and Delivery: This activity deals with the transportation and delivery of the charter vessel from the ship owner to the designated location. It includes discussions about the schedule, loading and unloading

Hi Ms. Morris,                    We have an enquiry for 13,000MT of rice from Colombo to Matadi. Can you give us a berth congestion forecast and how does your laytime allowance work in case of port delays?                    Many thanks,                    Robert
Email 2:
Matadi is a very busy port with cargoes often backed up at berth. There is no guaranteed transit time to discharge ships. It is typical for ships to be waiting in line from 2-4 days to get to berth and there is not a predictable number of ships in line to discharge as ships can come at any time without warning.
                
                It is typical to run back up and sometimes 2 berths simultaneously. When two berths are available, the berthing order is typically handled by the Terminal based on when the ship can reach the berth. In the event that your vessel can reach the berth on the day that is scheduled for your vessel, your berth time will likely be honored. If you are late due to port congestion and cannot reach the berth that is reserved for you, your berth may be given to another ship and you will have to wait in line for the next

Email 1:
Dear Zara,                    Hello. We can load the gasoline at Jubail April 15th. What can you do about voyage charter terms?                    Regards,                    James                    NOTE: A typical voyage charter (demurrage) contract has 24 hours as the benchmark for demurrage/laytime (load time to commence). Beyond this point the charterer becomes liable for demurrage for each day over the 24 hour benchmark.                    Now reply to Email C in the same style.                    Email D:                    Dear Captain Ford,                    I have noted your early availability and am trying to find if any interest at this time for gasoline from Jubail. amount of money (of course with a very high margin of profit for them).

for you. The following is the technical background:

between Brazil and Venezuela. This ship was specially chartered by a
tour operator from Dubai who asked us for help

using the forkl

A booking reference number is a unique number that is given to a customer when they make a booking for a product or service. The number is used to identify the customer's booking and to keep track of it. The number may be given to the customer in a confirmation email or letter, or it may be printed on the customer's booking form. The booking reference number is typically used to look up the customer's booking when they call or email to ask a question or make a change to their booking.

Answering both of these emails at the same time is often not possible. Even with the help of tools, like Changelog.io , can save time. 
Typically, you would need to spend some time each day, looking through the emails you’ve gotten, and only answer the ones you can actually answer, saving the others for later. 

A chat bot can also do that. With a Machine Learning and NLP model, the bot can answer the questions that it has answers to, or store them to answer later, and reply to your other colleagues later, with their questions still in place.

Email 1:
Mr. Silver,                    We’re looking for a 500 ton cargo of corn from Quebec to Tokyo. Could you provide a freight quote under CFR terms, and can your vessel sail before the 20th?                    Best regards,                    Gordon
Email 2:
Silver Shipping
Mr. Silver,
Thank you for your reply. We have already loaded on a vessel and made the transportation contract. However, the transportation company asks for the following documents: a set of bills of lading, a certificate of insurance and a set of commercial invoices. I would appreciate your advice.
Yours sincerely,
Tom

The problem of Cargo Document is tricky because it involves the dispute on whether the transportation company should be considered as the agent of the seller.

Business background:
The first email shows that the buyers have agreed on an acceptance to offer (letter of acceptance, cf. § 1384, Italian Code of Commercial law (Codice Commerciale)) and made a transportation contract for the 500 ton cargo of corn with a third party. As for the Seller, the second email shows that the Seller still thinks that the transportation company is his agent and the Buyers are not
Email 3:
Dear Gordon,
Silver Shipping, Inc. is currently arranging the shipping for you. It will be more convenient if you could tell us the name of the third party or the transportation company to deal with the shipping contract. We are looking forward to getting your email. Thank you very much.
Yours sincerely,
Michael Silver, President Silver Shipping, Inc.
</Email 3>

The main issue:
For the transaction to be a sale with CIF clause, at the moment of conclusion of the contract of sale, the Seller and the Buyers have to agree on the destination port and the Seller have to insure the goods for the Buyers. If the Buyers do not have a transportation contract, the Seller must comply with this CIF clause to fulfill the contract. Otherwise, the Seller should not promise the contract with the Buyers at all, which is the same as Article 6 § 1 (c) of the ICC
Email 4:
Gordon,
Mr. Silver would like to know where you have got the buyers of the corn. We have already got buyers but you asked for the freight and insurance costs. We do not understand why. As we agreed, you are responsible for the sale, insurance and transportation of the corn. We expect to see a written transportation contract from you within the next 3 days. Please forward to Mr. Silver a copy of the transportation contract.
Yours sincerely,
Bill
</Email 4>
The point is that the Seller has not decided what destination port the Buyers are going to choose yet. It seems that the Sellers have fulfilled all the CIF obligations in this case. Thus, it is unnecessary to involve any transportation company. If there is no such transportation company that the Seller and the Buyers both use, the contract of sale cannot be considered as a CIF contract. Therefore, the Sellers should not

Email 1:
Hi Kathy,                    Has the grounding of the Seablue had any impact on your crude fixing level for the short term?                    Thanks,                    Blayney
Email 2:
Hi Blayney,                    Not at all.                    Seablue is a crude vessel and almost all crude cargoes have been fixed by the other time-chartered tankers coming out of  Chinese yards.
As I mentioned previously, if Seablue did not come out in China, other tankers would come out of the dock and China would be fixed.                    These tankers would operate at a price level set by the most competitive time charter tanker which is the drydocked Seablue and therefore the price level at which China is fixed would not be different even if Seablue was out of the drydock.
LPG cargoes are different since we can not use LPG in the crude tankers and crude cargoes are not as easy to fix as LPG, since many producers are contracted and certain prices are set.

Email 1:
Hello Ms. Scott,                    Can you look at the market rate for 2 x 50foot containers of crude oil from Balikpapan to Jakarta, 22nd to 23rd of the month?                    Regards,                    Emma
Email 2:
Hi,                    We bought 2 x 50foot containers of crude oil from Balikpapan to Jakarta for 700 USD.                    All the best,                    Emma

After investigating 82 oil container rates in Balikpapan from February to May 2016, Emma wrote email 1 to request advice on market rates for the 22nd to 23rd of the month. When the suggested rate was below market rate, she accepted the offer via email 2.

Solution:
The correct answer is a2, and the explanation is as follows:
The business communication has the characteristic of taking the buyer's interest into consideration. The buyer is assumed to be the focus in business communication.
Email 3:
Dear Ms. Scott,                   We would like to purchase some crude oil. We have a request for a load of cargo delivered to China on or around the 22nd to 23rd of this month. What is the market rate for this?                    Regards,                    Emma

Answer Options:
a1. Email 3 asked the oil supplier for the market rate of oil containers and the price, which shows great concern for the buyer's interest.
a2. The oil supplier provides a quotation below the market rate in email 4, showing concern for the buyer's interest.
a3. The oil supplier provided a quotation that was on par with the market rate in email 4, showing no concern for the buyer's interest.
a4. The oil supplier provided a quotation that was much higher than the market rate in email 4, showing great concern for the buyer's interest.
a5

Email 1:
Hi John,                    Our Singapore client would like to transport 2,800MT of naphtha from Baltimore to Dahej, but we don’t have enough funds on hand for the margin fee. Could you spot us?                    Hope you can help.                    Kim
Email 2:
From: John G                 Sent: 23 February 2012 18:00                 To: Kim T                 Subject: Spot us?                 Not a chance! Hope you can spot my answer.                 John

Problem

A recent widespread email spam campaign targeted the energy and commodities trading industry with messages claiming that their customers wanted to use their services to buy crude oil and related products from reputable traders in the market. Some traders were approached in a very business-like manner, allegedly by major oil firms. The email subject line would indicate that the email was from a trusted business partner, such as a large energy firm or similar corporate client.

The email requests are easy to read but hard to understand. A foreign sounding person claiming to be an executive from a respectable company in a similar industry wants to “spot” some “margin fee” – what? An explanation for what these terms mean may have come attached
Email 3:
Dear John,                    Thank you for your reply.                    Our Singapore client is Singapore Energy, one of the leading trading and logistics companies in Asia Pacific. They represent a major Japanese refiner, Osaka Gas.                    It’s true that this is a complicated trading project and we have to pay a relatively high margin fee of USD 1,000.000.                    If you don’t mind, I can arrange to send you the contract and payment procedure, so that you can fully understand the situation.                    Have a good day.                    Kim

When a business receives a large unsolicited order they often feel obligated to make the sale. In this instance, we can probably deduce that our client is confused as to what the client actually wants and also may be uncomfortable with all the business jargon. In both situations, the client should take a step back and evaluate the order. First, the client should
Email 4:
Dear John,                    Thank you for your reply.                    I am really sorry to trouble you. My name is Alihac, Assistant to the CEO of Singapore Energy.                    I’d like to discuss with you about the details of the project.                    Please let me know when you are free.                    Best regards,                    Kim

As the requests are unsolicited and we have not received any communication with our buyer in the past, it would be a good idea to contact them directly to confirm their intent. We could ask the buyer for more information and maybe arrange to speak with the buyer directly. When speaking with the buyer, it would be important to ask them to provide more information about the deal. The buyer may have a reasonable explanation for their request. However, it is important to keep in mind that a reasonable explanation does not necessarily mean the request is legitimate.

Conclusion

This type of email scam

Thanks, Reza

Below is Rosalind's reaction to Reza's invitation.
Email 3:
You are good, its working perfect :)

All the best,
Rosalind

So she already appreciated the role of Reza’s proposing concrete example as shown in the second email above.

For general reference, a LSA is a LOI (letter of intent) document.

Introduction

The use of “Email 1” as an example is taken from a popular LinkedIn post of Sam Nara on the subject of using a working example when making a proposal (source: Linkedin).

I have learned a lot from Sam’s post, and I think the post helps provide an excellent practical starting point. In this post, I will provide further explanations to highlight more subtle points not included in Sam’s original post, and also discuss how these points are implemented in our Lean Email.

Email 1 is a typical email. Its objective is to propose a working example to a recipient.

In practice, Rosalind
Email 4:
Thank you so much!
<...>
I do need your help here to review and submit the revised LSA to admin for approvals!

In this example, Rosalind first thanked Reza for sending her a revised LSA, then reminded Reza that she required his help to proceed with the transaction.

Based on this email, Reza needs to do two things to support Rosalind in closing this transaction:

• Review the LSA before submitting the LSA to Rosalind’s admin for approvals.
• Submit the LSA to Rosalind’s admin for approvals.

Reza can do these two tasks simply by using Lean Email by clicking the buttons as shown below. Clicking on the Review button will pop-up a Review/Submit page, which contains a Review tab, and a Submit tab.

Clicking on the Review tab, Reza can simply enter a quick review note, and

Email 1:
Dear Ms. Armitage,                    Want to discuss options for a scheduled bulk chartered from Singapore to Jakarta, loading 15,000 MT of rice.                    Thanks,                    Sally
Email 2:
Ms. Armitage                    Hi Sally,                In reference to your email, we may consider to organize a chartered out of Singapore with loading to be completed by around 20 to 22 Nov, with delivery ETA expected to be around 10 to 12 Dec. </Email 2>

# Word Problem

### Solution 1

From the email the relevant facts are:

• The farmer wants to charter a ship to transport 15000 mt of rice to Jakarta.
• According to Ms. Armitage, the loading can be completed by around 20–22 November with delivery ETA around 10–12 December.

We know the ship will depart Singapore to Jakarta but
Email 3:
Hi Sally,                There will be another chartered starting from Singapore to Jakarta, departing on 18 Nov.                If you are interested, please advise latest by 15 Nov.                Regards,                Tony

</Email 3>

The sender mentions in Email 3 that the ship will leave Singapore to Jakarta on 18 November. That means there will be a time difference between 18 November and 20 November. So this information is not consistent with the information given in Email 2, which is the main source of information.

One reason for inconsistency could be the mistake in Email 2, when Ms. Armitage wrote 22 November instead of 20 November. Or one may assume that when Ms. Armitage sent Email 2, she didn't know about the departure date on 18 November.

Let us consider the following situation:
Email 4:
Hi Sally,                There will be a chartered departing on 18 Nov, with delivery ETA expected to be around 10 to 12 Dec.                Please advise if you are interested by 15 Nov.                Regards,                Tony

</Email 4>

In Email 4, we assumed that Ms. Armitage may have made a mistake in Email 2, and corrected it in Email 4. So let us analyze this situation.

Assume the ship leaves Singapore on 18 November and arrives at Jakarta on 10 December. This means the ship will take 22 days to reach Jakarta.

So, if loading is completed on 20 November, it will take a minimum of 2 days to complete the loading. It may take longer.

• So the loading will take place between 18 and 20 November.
• Then, if the

Dear Felipe,                 25,000 tons of oil from Copenhagen to Lagos in a seven-day freight?                    That's quite a bit of oil, Felipe. I assume you need to ship it by sea.                    You see, the oil trade operates on a just-in-time inventory management model, whereby oil is shipped to tankers as needed. This provides a stable supply and demand, eliminates inventory storage costs and prevents oil from degrading over time.                    Since your request involves shipping 25,000 tons of oil in seven days, my freight quote estimate would exceed what is available.                    Please confirm that your request is for 25,000 tons of oil in a seven-day freight and I can provide a quote to the maximum that is available to my company. Email 1:
Dear Ms. Anderson,                    The vessel will leave Porto Velho on 24th April. Can you confirm berth allocation?                    Regards,                    Kim                Sample email 1
            Communication is key to having a successful voyage. This is why there are six key elements to an email.
            The First Element - Greetings
            Emails are business documents, so you should use formal language. This includes starting the email with a formal greeting. Formal greetings can be used with someone who you are not familiar with. Some formal greetings include:
            Dear Mr Xander,
            Greetings Ms. Anderson,
            To whom it may concern.
            The Second Element - Subject Line
            Use a descriptive subject line. One you give your email a descriptive subject line, you will increase your chances of being read. It will also prevent your emails from being mistaken for spam or getting lost in your recipient
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Simon,                      The vessel will leave Porto Velho on 24th April. Can you confirm berth allocation?                    Regards,                    Kim
    Elements of an Email
    The Third Element - Body of the Email
    The body of your email should include:
    Introduce yourself to the recipient. If it is your first time contacting the recipient, introduce yourself in your first email. An introduction should include:
    Why are you writing?
    Why do you think the recipient would be interested in your email?
    Include an appropriate closing for your email. To find a list of appropriate closings, see below.
    Sincerely,
    Cordially,
    Regards,
    Best regards,
    Kind regards,
    Best,
    Finally, it is recommended that you proofread your email before you send it. It is important that your email is clear, concise, and professional.

Email 1: Hi James, Looking to move 5,8kmt of palm kernel oil from Port Klang to Male. Can you advise how the refrigeration is done in the holds. Cheers, Mona Email 2: Dear Mona, The refrigeration is done by ventilation - the holds are ventilated by system that draws air through ice cold seawater. The air is then used to keep the goods at right temperature. There is no refrigeration in the holds of our ships. In between, there are rooms for packages of bulk goods. We could load the PKE in these rooms. It should fit in one or two such rooms. The loading rate would be 7-8t per hour. The max weight per carcase is 1.500kg. The container could not handle heavier carcases. To prevent damage of the PKE during loading, we have made special arrangements for the loading. The shell of the PKE must be closed after being loaded and we suggest using special sealing material for this purpose. A sample of this material can be sent if you wish. Should you Email 3: Hi James, That sounds good. I can arrange the product to arrive in 20 ft containers. The dimensions are as follows: The biggest one is 140cm x 75cm x 37cm and the heaviest is 1270kgs. We need 5 containers. I can arrange the sealing material, do you have the dimensions of the rooms you have in mind? Thanks again. Mona Email 4: Dear Mona, The rooms are about 8,5m by 2,9m, 2,8m high. That should be sufficient. A container is the best to move it. We have also made arrangements for transporting the PKE in ISO containers. If you have difficulties to do so, we could also load the goods at our port in Port Klang, moving the goods in our own trucks from there. Should you have further questions, please let me know. >>> rule = '''.*Freight.*?to (.*)'''.strip()

## Reference number

Not present

## Vocabulary (1)

- **10k** 10,000
- **.5** 1/2, half

## Adverbs

**On** **October 25th**
Email 3:
Dear Madame/Sir
We are looking for a voyage from October 25th to 28th for 26,000MT.

To **be looking** **for** a voyage

To **do** something, the subject is doing, the action. 

Compare:
To **be** waiting for a friend.

We are looking for a voyage means that they need someone to buy their product.  

One must use the passive for this sentence. 
We have the object in the sentence - voyage.  This can be changed to object of the preposition **for** - voyage **for**.  
This change turns the whole sentence into the passive sentence.

The subject will be the preposition. 
We know this because the preposition **for** comes before the subject.  We can make it **a voyage**.

We are **looking** for **a voyage**

The question is
Email 4:
**Who** are **looking** **for** **a voyage**

Answer **They** are looking for a voyage. 

## Common mistake in student papers

1. Using the active form for these sentences.  

We do not use the active form when there is a preposition after the subject.  
It should be  
**He** is looking **for** a house. 
We have the active form **He** is looking, but **for** comes after it.
We change the active form to the passive form, thus creating the passive form.

**There** is looking **for** a house.

2. Removing the article. 

The article **a** is required to make the sentence active.  
**He** is looking **for** a house.  
If you remove **a**, you have created a passive sentence.

<Email 4>:
**Who** is looking

Hi Gracie,

This snippet represents two separate emails. The first emails are typical types of emails in any trade conversation. They represent the customer asking for the shipping schedule for May and for the best shipping quote for that date. In email 3, the customer sends the complete address.

The customer appears to have followed up again with an email to ask about a different date. Nakamura responds again by asking to wait for
Email 4:
Hi Gracie,
Thank you for your email. I will wait for your reply.

...[while Nakamura leaves for vacation. Nakamura's email box remains empty for a month, and she does not respond to Gracie's email.]

## 1 Answer

Nakamura would have followed up on the request as soon as possible; Nakamura was probably away on vacation for most of that time, so the email system was empty.

I think Nakamura could have sent an auto-responder or had her colleagues respond to email queries for her, while she was on vacation.

My job as a Process Safety Coordinator for a company operating in various Asian countries, I often have to send emails in Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and Thai.  I’ve never needed to be away from my job for an extended period of time.

The agents can respond to each other immediately as they have all the necessary details for the booking in their possession and do not need to go back to their customers.

Since the offers from buyers and sellers are decentralized, they will not be able to negotiate prices and they will have to agree to the market price and then move on to the next negotiation.

If both agents reply to the sender with the same message, there will be an error because a double response is not allowed in TPN. Thus, there is a restriction against these situations to facilitate the tracking of pending operations.

In the third case, it is possible to get a counter-offer or a quote by the other

# @mentions
## Setup

We have the ability to mention people with @username. For example, mentioning @taylorotwell will notify Taylor Otwell that you mentioned them.

We use Laravel notifications internally, so if someone mentioned you and has their notification settings set up, they'll be notified of the mention.

To handle mentions in your own apps, simply listen for the Event:NotificationEvent which is sent when @mentions are posted.

See the Notifications documentation for more information.

# Text Formatting
#### Headers

##### Second Level Header
###### Third Level Header

###### Numbered List
```
This is my
Email 4:
Hi Fred, my name is Joe and I'm responsible for shipping for Rob's division. If you have a rate you'd be willing to send, I'd be happy to put the business your way.

  1. First item in the list
  2. Another item
```
```
1. First item in the list
2. Another item
```
##### Code

To format inline code, enclose it in backticks `like this`. To include a literal backtick, precede it with a backslash `like this`.

To format a block of code, indent it by four spaces (standard indentation in Markdown) or surround it with triple backticks ``` .

```javascript
var foo = 'bar';
```
                    ```ruby
class Foo
  def initialize(foo)
    @foo = foo
  end
end
```

Email 2:
Hi Kristina,                It's in the $90s/ton (FOB Nola) at the moment. Rates are firm at this level, since very few tonnage is being offered. Also, considering the port congestion in Houston, we would only sign a charter party once we have the deal in hand. Should the charter party contain a destination clause, then of course, it could be signed upon final confirmation.               Regards, Alex

Comment:
Notice the commercial terms are spoken in term of shipping industry currency: MT, t, per ton, etc.
Email 3:
Here in Norway, it's our currency, the Krone, that is used. So here goes our deal in the local currency:

3,300,000/MT (FOB Nola)

A charter party may be drawn up to cover our terms. But, if the MEG should arrive a bit early, we could store the cargo until we need it.

Best, Kris.

Comment:
Here we have the commercial terms expressed in terms of "3,300,000/MT" instead of "per ton". In our example, 3,300,000 is the same as $90. The reason for the discrepancy is that Kristina, the seller, is located in Oslo, Norway, and the selling price is denominated in Norwegian Krone (NOK). One NOK equals 0.16 USD.

Email 1:
Hello Capt. Hu,                    We are organizing a 200,000mt cargo of MGO from Gijon, Spain, to Japan. As you know, it’s a big shipment. In your opinion, are all the suppliers out there able to supply such a big order?                    Also, how long will the loading time take?                    Many thanks,                    Timothy
Email 2:
Dear Tim,             I'm going to refer to my first email response and elaborate as requested.             We’ve never sold that quantity of MGO. Our company is a division of a larger company that has supplied 100,000mt+ to major trading companies in the last few years, so we can do this. The time frame can be negotiated between the supplier and buyer. We usually provide the shipping documents within 10-12 days of the shipment and request payment in cash 4 weeks later. The buyer needs to pay the bank documentary charges within 2 weeks of the shipment.             I think the real trick is to find a supplier who is able to supply this quantity. To find a supplier for 200,000mt who is able to deliver such a big order is quite challenging. The order should be split into two parts, each part being around 100,000mt.
Email 3:
I’ve just learned that the delivery vessel has a limit of 130,000mt and two big ships might be needed. So, 100,000mt of the order might be enough to fill one ship, and the other ship will have to be loaded with the other 100,000mt.             There are many shipping vessels available that can take this amount of cargo. The average delivery time for this kind of shipment is around 45 days, although it’s possible to shorten the delivery time. It depends on the cargo vessel’s available route.             The costs for this shipment can vary from USD 10 to USD 20 per mt, depending on the size of the cargo vessel, the route taken, and the distance the cargo will have to travel.             In conclusion, I think the best course of action is to ship the order in two parts, each part being around 100
Email 4:
I will continue to provide information on how to find a supplier and transport and shipping companies for this type of shipment.             The best way to find a supplier is to contact the local trade association or trade missions in your area. They can help you find a local supplier, and if there’s no local supplier, they can refer you to the association or missions in the destination country.             There are several types of shipping vessels that can take this amount of cargo. The most common types are bulk carriers, tankers, container ships, and Ro-Ro (Roll-on/roll-off) vessels. Each type of vessel has its own advantages and disadvantages.             The most common route is from Europe to Japan. In any dialogue it is important to state facts and not omit or conceal important information. This gives room for miscommunication as well as mistrust between the two sides. That’s why it is important to understand how to communicate professionally in business correspondence.

## What is Business Correspondence?

A message sent and received via a written form is known as a business correspondence. It is crucial as it provides information on the various activities of an organization. There are several forms of business correspondence. They include formal business letters, e-mails, and memos.

The letter types might be used to communicate with customers, clients, or employees. Some examples of business correspondence include application letters

They show up in email. When you google “ur5 quickbooks” and “quickbooks error 176109”, you’ll find this email. They are low cost replicas of your computer’s typical shipping and air delivery errors. One reason why they’re so effective is because they’re 100% human-friendly, like “Q: When will the goods arrive? A: Today.”

When you send them back, they’ll respond. These two replies will let you know that someone from them (and not a computer, and certainly not an imposter) is in your inbox.

If you’re not going to send them a reply, or if you’re going to turn

Email 1:
Hi Ms. Morrow,                    We have just received confirmation for 3,200MT phosphates from Casablanca to Lisbon. Can you confirm your offer to carry this cargo?                    Regards,                    Ishaan
Email 2:
Hi Ishaan,                    Please find attached a Confirmation of Arrival. Can you let us know when this cargo is coming?                    Regards,                    Sarah 

1. Which type of communication did Sarah use in <Email 2>?
Answer: Email

2. What might Sarah's Confirmation of Arrival be?
Answer: A document that outlines information about the shipping procedure for the cargo.
Email 3:
Sarah:                    Hi, Ishaan.                    When will this cargo be arriving? 
                    Ishaan:                    The cargo should be arriving on October 6.                    Are you ready for it? 

3. What type of shipping route is the cargo taking?
Answer: This is a sea route.

4. Why does Sarah ask about the arrival date?
Answer: To plan for the arrival and preparation of the cargo.

<Email 4>:
Sarah:                    Okay, we're all set!                    I'll be expecting the cargo on the 6th of October.                    Ishaan:                    Great! I'll let the ship know.                    Talk to you soon! 

5. What is the reason for this email?
Answer: To confirm the cargo's arrival date and arrange for the cargo's reception.

6. What does "all set" mean in this context?
Answer

There are 47 emails that look like this, each filled with valuable
information, contact info, and requests from scammers.

Following these scams' leads, investigators can map out the chain of
people behind the scam, determine the next target, and watch them open
suspicious links or respond to scam emails. An analysis of the replies
to this chain of emails shows that four or more people are involved
with creating and supporting these scams.

In a world of complex scams, one of the best methods of prevention
is education. The more people who are aware of and reject a scam, the
less impact it will have on those who don't know any better.

To this end, this data has been released to the public to help everyone
understand the impact of mass marketing scams. A few highlights of this
scam's attempt to fool millions of people include:

#Create a Chat Bot

A bot is an automated process that performs an action for you. You can send it a message and it will respond to your message and take action on your behalf. A Chat Bot is an example of a bot.

To create a chat bot we will be making a Github Repository, to use NodeJS, this is because:

• NodeJS is one of the most popular languages used in web development today.
• NodeJS allows you to run your code server-side, which means it can process data and respond to user interactions in real time.
• NodeJS also supports JavaScript, which is a great way to get started with programming. It's an easy language to learn, and many developers already know it.
•

Once again, my valued guest and the popular ‘humourous’ founder of the humour site Fuleminess  has raised a very important issue. With the growing influence of multinational business and the Internet, there is a danger of being misunderstood. Particularly when it comes to asking someone a question. With the ever growing number of emails and phonecalls being made globally every second of the day, it is important to ensure your request is heard. 

When sending an email with a question, it is also very important to include a sign off such as “Best Regards” or “Kind Regards” this is because at times a person can read the email very fast and can be assumed that the person sending the email is actually sending them

<Betsy to her husband, Dave>:
Here we go again! This is the third request for a quote in one day, and David seems to have given a full quote in his original email. Why do I have to explain this to him every time?
What are some reasons for replying to an email twice?
Paragraph 2 (this one) gives specific reasons in the writer’s first email. Her husband’s email serves to remind her that David is not as familiar with the company’s rates as she is.

Explain how this form of explanation might serve to establish greater rapport
Email 3:
Hi Dave,                    Why don’t you just offer the rate per ton and let David accept it or suggest alternatives?                    Do you remember in our training course, we learnt that the purpose of most email communications is not just to reply with ‘yes’ or ‘no’, but to help others make a decision?                    David’s just a little reluctant, but he will accept it and agree to it if you can help him to make a decision by making your rate specific enough.                    Best wishes,                    Betsy

Dear Mr. Ferris,                    My name is Samuel. I’m currently the vessel broker of a Chinese bulk carrier currently in Chittagong, Bangladesh.                    We have 3,800MT of heavy plates to load. Destination is Port Louis, Mauritius. We have been given the following port dues and fees to be deducted from the cargo:                    * General Cargo Port Dues: USD 3,256.00                    * Coast Guard Charges: USD 164.00                    * MFAF (Mauritius Free Airport Fee): USD 112.80                    * Port Corporation: USD 159.84                    * Generator Rental: USD 0.16/ Hour * 12 Hours = USD 1.92                    * Empty Tank Cleaning: USD 10.00 * 2 Tanks = USD 20.00                    Could you kindly take this into account when submitting
Email 2:
Dear Samuel,
Thank you for your email. Unfortunately it is not appropriate for you to pass charges like this on to the cargo owners without their consent. If you are able to provide evidence that this is the owners’ responsibility (e.g. a bill of lading with a clause allowing the carrier to deduct port dues from the cargo), we might be able to discuss a rate increase to cover these expenses, but if you are just making up charges to pay your agency then it is unethical and we will not pay you.
Thank you,
Alain Ferris
PS: We also need a few more details on the cargo (origin, grade, product code), which will enable us to get a more accurate quote for the freight.
PPS: The more information you are able to provide in your emails, the faster we can give you an answer, and the less likely it is that you will have

1. The Suez Canal plays a crucial role in the global shipping industry, connecting the Mediterranean Sea to the Red Sea. However, recent events have caused concerns among vessel operators and shipping companies about delays and increased congestion at the canal.
2. Since the closure of the canal in March due to the Ever Given ship blocking it, operators have been expressing fears of congestion and delays. Despite the reopening of the canal in mid-April, vessels are still facing delays as the backlog of shipping containers and other cargo continues to accumulate.

Hey All,                     Because I’m out of the office this week, I’m sending you some interesting projects and news to check out while I’m away!  Here are a few highlights:
* Click here to learn about the Fertilizer Institute’s new Code of Conduct, which includes nine guiding principles for good behavior, including the encouragement of a culture of safety and compliance with the law. "Anyone who works with anhydrous ammonia or other fertilizers must read this, and they must share it with their teams," says Director of Regulatory Affairs Brian Jennings.
* When a group of California manufacturers and distributors went before the California Air Resources Board (CARB) to discuss the 2013 Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) proposed by the U.S. EPA, they did not leave empty-handed. A bill was introduced in the state legislature that would provide a tax incentive to encourage renewable fuel blending

Email 2:
Good morning Caroline,

I have checked with my Bitumen supplier.

### Answer options

The correct answer is C.   We need 1,300MT of bitumen


  • A.  We need 1,300MT of bitumen to Chicago                    • B.  I have checked with my supplier                    • D.  Could you name some vessels and a laycan?                    • E.  I wanted to see if we could coordinate our movements to Lyon


The best thing to do when faced with answer options is to try and make as few assumptions as possible. Although the words "we need" in the original email suggests a second person, you shouldn't immediately assume that there is more than one person at SEEDOR Company.
Try and identify the people who are talking about the 1,300MT.
The correct answer is "we".  So, this 1

In my previous post I introduced how the transformer can be used to set up a casual model using a combination of supervised and unsupervised learning. I wanted to apply this methodology to email correspondence analysis but had no good starting points to learn from. So, I decided to have a go at using a large email data set to set up an email correspondence model. In this post, I’ll describe my method and then evaluate it.
## Previous Work
I found two other email correspondence analyses:
Both papers claimed to have a small error rate (below 5%) but no error rate figures were provided. Their methods included analyzing only the destination of emails and ignoring the subjects and whether the email was replied to or not.

Hi Basil,                    Could you handle 5,400MT of vegetable oil from Aqaba to Mombasa, with full documentation? And how much is your storage fee?                    Regards,                    Sina
Email 2:
From: _Sina?_
To: _Ivan?_
Sent: _Thursday, August 19, 2010 9:17:08 AM_
Subject: RE: Storage

> How much is your storage fee? 


   _> And who will deliver this quantity to our factory?_ 

So, there was this corporation who asked about our storage and delivery cost. First question they asked was about storage cost. I made sure to talk about all different prices based on different quantities and then I explained the storage conditions. I never mentioned that in my price I included free delivery to the factory, in my opinion it is better to ask all questions before talking about details. You do not know what questions they can ask.

When I received the email below, I was a bit shocked about the question. However I managed to answer it quickly as follows:

Sina

From:
Email 3:
> _We can handle your storage in Mombasa. The price is 1.2$/MT on 1 month with total quantity of 5,400MTs. We can deliver the cargo by truck directly to your factory. But the price depends on the distance._ 


> _For example, from Mombasa port to Machakos it is 70 Km. The price is 40/MT. From Mombasa to Athi river it is 50KM. The price is 30/MT._


> _Regards, Basil_ 


Dear Sina, Thank you for your email. We can handle your storage in Mombasa. The price is 1.2$/MT on 1 month with total quantity of 5,400MTs. We can deliver the cargo by truck directly to your factory. But the price depends on the distance. For

I would like to share with you a couple of situations I have recently experienced regarding sales. The main factor here is that every port of origin in this region has its own cargo’s name that differs from one port to another. Let me give you an example. Vung Tau’s oil is usually known as “XONE”, for example. If the cargo’s origin was not Vung Tau, it would be known as something different. In the first email, the seller is probably from Vung Tau, the port
Email 3:
<3>
Thanks for your email.                    We have an available vessel. Could you please share the port of origin?                    Thanks.                    Best regards,                    [Your name]                    [Your address]

so he doesn’t want to use the common port of origin name, but he wants to use the name of the port where his product originates from.

We have, however, to be cautious when receiving information from an agent, because often it is not completely correct. If the agent wants to sell his cargo by using an incorrect cargo name, it is much easier for him to trick the buyer by giving a name that has a higher profit for him, or a name that is more familiar for the potential buyer. This issue is something that we have to be aware of. We have to make sure that the cargo is what we think it is, and if we’re sure that we know the exact

They get a reply to only the last email. There are reasons why they could be having difficulty in getting through to their target. This happens frequently when it comes to end-user targets in emerging markets.
I always leave two days in my inbox to send another follow up email after the first one is sent and then at the end of the day send another one. This seems to work better than the more traditional 3-day/3-email rule.

While we see high open rates, it’s possible that the real target isn’t looking for the product at this time and may not have read the email. You don’t really know for sure unless you get a reply from the target

<Email 4>:
 On Mon, May 20, 2019 at 05:54 PM,  wrote:

* Why the captain and other crew leave the bridge, walk away from the wheel, and forget where the wheel is? Is this typical, or is it just human nature?

 It is not typical. Any crew that is leaving the bridge for more than a few minutes will usually assign a watchkeeper and/or specify exactly where the wheel is. If the owner insists on an automatic pilot watchkeeper, it is up to the captain to comply. But that would not be my recommendation.

* If the vessel is in or near a harbor or channel where there are many vessels and navigating is a challenge, why do the ships leave the bridge and let the ship just drift out of control? Would not knowing exactly where the wheel is be a problem? I am talking about not having a person at the helm ready

Dear <NAME>,
I am writing to you because I am highly interested in computer engineering and in designing advanced technology, and I want to know what steps I can take to reach my goal. I want to know what work and learning opportunities are available in computer engineering. I have found out a lot about computer engineering and I have done the research. I want to know what path I need to take to become successful in computer engineering. I have taken a number of classes and learned about the core material that I need for computer engineering.
I want to have more information about computer engineering and what experiences you had in this field. I want to know what steps you took to get to where you are now, and what I need to do to get there. I have done some research, but I do not know what my next step is.
I want to know what classes I should take and what organizations
Email 3:

My name is <NAME>. I would like to write to you for a few questions that have been bugging me. I have heard of many stories about how to get into a career path I am interested in, and I am wondering which one to follow. I’m interested in psychology as a career and have tried to look into what steps I need to take to get where I want to be.
I would like to know what steps I should take to become successful in psychology. I know that I need to major in psychology and complete my requirements. I also know that there are many other requirements to become successful, like doing internships and taking many more classes. I want to know what your experience was, and what I need to do to get where you are now.
Thank you for your time,

Email 2:
dave,                    look at the surface tanker jet fuel route chart on the www and do the calculations. The distance is only 275 miles and if you cut through the shallows then it's maybe only 250 miles.                    With the shallowest part 43 feet, a 35,000 ton tanker would only use about 16' of water to float. If a tanker could travel through the route, I'm sure that the insurance premiums wouldn't be a major problem.                    I could not find any such tanker out there right now so it's not a matter of just connecting the dots.                    The insurance companies would calculate that if there is a loss, there is no place for the ship to refuel on the route, so the insurance rates might be higher.                    Bob

Email 2:
Hi Ivy,
Good morning.

The order for 2,500MT should be easy to manage.
Regarding the order for 1,500MT of grain, unfortunately, we do not see any vessel available to fit both cargoes in the same vessel. As we are still in June, there are still some free slots available on July, but as the order size is so big, we have limited choices.
That being said, we can manage to fit 1,000MT of milk powder and 1,500MT of grain in the same vessel with the owner of a 10,000dwt M/V which is due to discharge the previous cargo in July. All details about the vessel are as follows:

M/V T1
Type    General Cargo
Flag    Liberia
Call    MOYO
Deadweight    8,600MT
Built    1996
Hold No
Email 3:

I know the situation seems very bad. I can only offer you the best available. If you are willing to wait till October, I can offer you a better slot with more space. This way, you will be able to fit more products, or reduce the price.

Martin

Email 1:
<BEGIN EMAIL C>                    Ms. Stevens:                    I will be at your office tomorrow for 30 minutes. Please let me know if you're free or if you want to meet elsewhere.                    Sincerely,                    Nastya
Email 2:
<BEGIN EMAIL C>                    I'm totally free tomorrow. See you tomorrow!                    Sincerely,                    Nastya

One of my workmates asked me how to answer this email. I am not sure myself. I've answered questions like these one here, but they were much more easy:

1)  Say good night to Mommy!
2)  Well, take your time!
3)  Of course I'll help you. When and where?
4)  That sounds great! I'll bring the umbrella.
5)  I know. It is not important.

What is the correct way to answer to Nastya in this email?

There is a pattern for this type of 2-part email that I've observed in some specific contexts:

1. The first part is like a sign-off: "Sincerely, Nastya". 2. The second part is the
Email 3:
<My name here> looks forward to your response.
<Email 4>:
<My name here> looks forward to speaking with you further.
<Email 5>:
<My name here> looks forward to meeting with you.
<Email 6>:
<My name here> looks forward to your call.
<Email 7>:
<My name here> looks forward to learning more about your situation.


This usage appears to be common in the auto industry, with online car reviews.

Here is a blog post on this, which cites a data-driven analysis from a company called Radian6:

https://hbr.org/2013/01/the-secret-language-of-email

If we take that at face value, then one possible answer to the email in the question is:

[EMAIL 8]
Please let me know if you're free or if you want to meet elsewhere.
[EMAIL 9]

Hi Jeremy,                   Thank you for the detailed information. The Port of Elizabeth is basically a bit “rustic”. Most of the coal is stored at berths which are up the hill or out of the water in a kind of side-loading facility. The coal berths are essentially ash ponds that are filled from barges, loaded from stockpiles, or loaded by rail. In any case, the coal must be transported in some way and the loading will depend on the coal berth. The average loading rate is between 600-800 mt/h, and with no draft restrictions or berthing limitations, we are expected to load at an average rate of 1500 mt/h. We can also do up to 2,000 mt/h if the coal can be delivered to the berth quickly and easily.

Be advised that in March, the water in the port will be very low. Because of

Q&A What’s the best time to use balticdirties?
When to use balticdirties ? Use balticdirties only if no other time charter data is available (e.g. in freight rate calculations). Typically, the day and time you check are important (e.g. if there is a tidal window). Do not use balticdirties in company charter party clauses if you have a term charter party clause. Use balticdirties at all other times. For example, if you are estimating spot freight rates between two ports and two locations, and you only

Email 4:
If you are in direct contact with the buyer, please try to get the material specification. In this case, you need to be direct and say that you cannot send a freight quotation without that document. If they ask about the freight quotation first, share a rough estimate with a mention that it will be updated when you have the material specification. The buyer should realize that this is the only way for you to take an offer. It is your first line of defense against waste of time. Other brokers might not understand that they need to ask for the material specification because they do not have a "ship" yet, so they can only discuss price and laycan. This is very wrong, but I am sure it happens.  If you are an agent, you should receive the material specification from the buyer. If you don't have it, call your counterpart to discuss this. Dear Drew
    1.  Your company shall provide a Letter of Credit in favor of Hapag-Lloyd (Shipping line)
    2.  You will be responsible for all taxes / duties and all associated costs including local, state and federal.
    3.  Your company will bear the cost of the shipment to include cost of packing and insurance.
    4.  The cost of the shipment shall be paid on the 10th day of the last month of every quarter.
    5.  Shipping schedule shall be agreed upon between your company and Hapag-Lloyd (Shipping line)
    6.  The shipment shall be delivered 30 days after shipment date.

                    Best regards,                   
                    Ting

P.S.  1000 Box is 2500.00 per tonne
    28,000 Box = 70,000

Email 2:
Hi Logan.                    Thanks for your email.                    Unfortunately, the shipping of pine from Vancouver to Inverness is banned by law. I’m afraid we’re going to have to pass on your shipment.                    Lyle

### ID or OID for the Importer?

Actually, there’s an alternative – the business needn’t try to find out whether the lumber is in compliance with U.S. law, but simply can certify to that effect. A problem arises in distinguishing between logs and lumber, and lumber that has been cut and sawn and lumber that is not sawn. And even a commitment to pay for a formal inspection would not be sufficient to get past U.S. Customs’ questions. So, when the importing country wishes to assure itself that U.S. law is being complied with, the issuing country may provide an assurance in the form of an import certificate, an export certificate,

Greetings Mrs. Bird,                    We are waiting on a number of tenders for an 8,000MT cargo of dry petcoke to Port Elizabeth. We’re currently unsure if the US Gulf can produce enough tonnage to meet our requirements. Can you please provide some estimated tonnages, and inform us of any other points of origin that could be competitive?                    Kind regards,                    Lewis
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Brereton,                    The M/V Ostende is due to load a cargo of Petcoke from Grays Harbor and delivery is scheduled for early November. The US Gulf is the only origin that we can produce in volume. Notice how the email itself doesn't go into the input? That's where everything gets tricky. If you're using input with the type of email, then you should just do the following:

For starters, if you're using Angular 2, you'll want to import FormsModule.

Like so: import { FormsModule } from '@angular/forms';
Next, you'll need to add FormsModule to the imports array in the @NgModule declaration.

Like so: imports: [ BrowserModule, FormsModule ],

And you'll need to add [email] to the input tag.

This will give you an input that looks something like this:

At the end of the day, I found it quite trivial, and I suspect that most people would, too.

Email 1:
I was interested in your article about refelective materials in Nature.                                         You had two equations for refractive index in the article.                                         I am trying to find a proof or derivation of one of those (the one that uses lambda and n) and wanted to see if you knew of a reference for it.                                         Thank you,                                         Daniel
Email 2:
Subject: f2=1-2n

Hi!

Thank you for your message. The equation n=1-sqrt(1-f)/2 is a very general one. It can be found in most books on electromagnetism and optics. I wrote down the reference where I first came across this equation in my Nature paper. Have a look at page 3. But you can also find it in more recent books on plasmonics. For example in a book by Jain.
Email 3:
Hello.

Do you have any notes or references for derivation of the equation, f2=1-2n, when n=4*Pi/lambda*d*n*d?

Thanks.

Daniel
Email 4:
Subject:  Re: f2=1-2n

Hi Daniel,

Your question is not directly related to this particular website, therefore I think I'll reply in an email.

The only literature I can think of are two references you probably already have found yourself:

(1)  P. Drude, Handbuch der Radiologie, Leipzig: Barth, 1922 (p. 369)

(2)  N. Jain, C. J. Kryzhanovsky, and C. H. Chen, Excitation and Detection of Surface Plasmons on Gold Films. In: T. Zimmermann, and A. Berger, eds., Coherence, Statistics, and Quantum Optics IV (Springer, 2005) 146-165

Drude's book is basically the bible on metallic materials in

Daniel

 Hello Kevin, Thank you so much for sending us a lovely song. Your friend Kevin is a great singer. Your English is really good, too. I'm happy you wrote to us. You can use "This is" to introduce your message. You can say something like "This is a song my friend Kevin sings." "This is an email I sent my friend Kelly last week." You can ask a question and talk about a movie like this: "How was the movie about the cat with a magic ability? It sounds interesting." Email 2:
Hi Jean,
Thank you for your email. I would like to ask you some information regarding your shipment of t-shirts:
1) What is the mark or brand of the t-shirts?
2) What type of t-shirt is it? Tank, tube, long sleeve, short sleeve?
3) Is the t-shirt knitted or woven?  And what kind of knit or weave?
4) Does it have any decoration on it? What type of decoration?
5) What type of fabric is it?  What is the denier, threads, and fiber count?
6) What is the weight of a t-shirt?
7) Do you want us to pay for the cost of freight, or do you want us to put it on your invoice?
8) How many items in one package?
If you have any questions, please feel free to ask.
Best regards,
Yue

Email 3:
At a first glance the email looks like the perfect email to send for this scenario; however, this is not the case as it is not very friendly. This could lead to someone feeling undermined, which could lead to the email recipient ignoring this email in hopes of less negativity from the sender. Which is the opposite of what we want. If we were to send this email to a sales person in hopes of securing the sale we would be sabotaging our chances of getting the sale because the person we are sending this to, may feel undermined and will respond less happily than if we had sent the second email. As well as providing a better response, the second email provides all of the information needed to complete the transaction and then asks for the decision. This shows professionalism and a desire to complete the transaction on both ends. In both cases the email offers the promise of a future reply, this may be the

The first email describes a negotiation for the sale of a commodity (in this case, maize). This kind of email, which we refer to as a negotiation email, is an important genre for a business that engages in negotiation with potential buyers and sellers. 

You can use such a negotiation email as an inspiration for your own, when you negotiate with a partner company. In the following paragraphs, I will discuss the parts of the above example email, showing you how they were composed, why they are important, and what the pros and
Email 3:

This is the reply to an inquiry email, i.e. an email that responds to a potential customer's inquiry about the products and services offered by a company. It contains all the information the recipient needs and provides enough context for her to make a decision, including the pricing and the delivery terms.

This is the end of the email, which is as important as its beginning. If the body of an email ends with a formality, it feels nice and appropriate to the recipient. However, if the ending part of the email contains information that does not pertain to the topic of the email, it may be confusing.

<SEND EMAIL C> ``` Import a Shipping Email dataset  Select  EMAILS in the  Model   section in the menu bar.  If you haven't done so yet, save your file by selecting the first tab in the bottom section of the view menu. After that, click on the plus button and select Import Dataset .  Finally, you will be directed to choose a file. This is a good point to download the dataset from the FISAI_22 assignment page and select the file Shipping Emails.xlsx .   When the upload is finished, you can check your data. Each shipping email will be represented by two different elements: ```   (Value, Time of writing, Sender, Recipient, Port of Departure, Port of Arrival)   <Value> <Time of writing> Mr/Ms <Sender> [Hamburg] Hi <Recipient>,              <Message>

Hello X,                    We want to charter a vessel to transport 2k MT of petroleum coke from Baku to Qingdao, China. Do you have any ship open in November?                    Regards,                    [name]
Email 2:
Hello,                    Best Price on spot by sea transport:                0,19 $/MT + 0,05$/MT bunker.                Subject: bunker..................  1/5 charter party done on GLS 2/5 cargo -petroleum coke - 20k MT 3/5 B/L paid - 100 % 4/5 sailing November 5/5 From - Baku, Azerbaijan to - Qingdao, China                Best Regards, [name]

What is the task?                    The task is to find an empty container, go to China (pay 0.19$/MT + 0.05$/MT bunker) and bring petroleum coke to Azerbaijan (20k MT, 100% B/L paid, sailing in November).

The main question for this task is, does the company have a vessel available to take the cargo?

What technique(s)
Email 3:
The main trick is to make this task look like it is for open charter. This makes the victim pay attention to the price, believing it is actually lower than the price of the chartered ship (by the way, let's make it 0.19$). By saying that you will pay 0.05$/MT for bunker, the victim thinks you are buying bunker, while you are actually renting the vessel.

    Also note that the shipping cost (0.19$) is given to the nearest part of the fourth decimal place, which might look suspicious if the sender and receiver have different countries. It is a very good trick to make such mistakes, as I did in email 2, or even in email 1 if the victim is inexperienced. It makes the victim think he is comparing two similar offers, which they are not, and look bad for not noticing it. Finally

The letter writer is trying to establish the availability of a service from a potential supplier. To do so, she needs to ask questions.
If you choose the service, the supplier may not think that you are interested in the product.  That is why Ms. Klein tells you that ships are expensive to operate and, thus, puts you in a more interested position.  On the other hand, you may not think that the service is suitable for your product.  This is why Ms. Klein suggests that you could provide the food.  In this case, the product is the food.  The product is the basis for the discussion.

Email 1:
Dear Mr. Flores,                    I would like to inquire about 4,700MT of naphtha from Istanbul to Zarafshan.                    If you are interested, we can begin negotiations based on your offer.                    Thank you,                    Susan
Email 2:
Dear Mr. Flores,                    According to your offer for naphtha, if you still have stock, we can negotiate based on your price.                    Susan

If the business person that you're trying to negotiate with sends an email that says, "Hello Susan," but it's really a spam bot that has auto-generated an email to look like it's from a human, the spam bot won't use your name in the reply.

According to your offer for naphtha

You can negotiate based on your price

We can begin negotiations based on your offer.

Therefore, if we see text in the email reply that doesn't match what we would expect a human to say in a negotiation reply, that's a good clue that it's a bot.

We didn't see any of that in your test cases, however. That's why I said the bot looks good. In fact, it looks
Email 3:
From: Dear Mr. Flores, I would like to inquire about 4,700MT of naphtha from Istanbul to Zarafshan. If you are interested, we can begin negotiations based on your offer. Thank you, Susan

<Email 4>:
From: Dear Mr. Flores, According to your offer for naphtha, if you still have stock, we can negotiate based on your price. Susan

much more complex than most bots out there, which usually just randomly grab a word from your email and reply with it.
Email 4:
From: Dear Mr. Flores, According to your offer for naphtha, if you still have stock, we can negotiate based on your price. Susan

much more complex than most bots out there, which usually just randomly grab a word from your email and reply with it.

<Email 4>:
 From: Dear Mr. Flores, According to your offer for naphtha, if you still have stock, we can negotiate based on your price. Susan

This would be an easy detection system for anyone who was trying to determine if an email reply was generated by a human or by a bot. It's not perfect (or rather, it's not "perfectly perfect"), but it is a way to detect spam bots.

However, what we're looking for is not just whether an email reply is generated by a bot, but whether the person that sent the email actually wrote that reply. Or in other words: Is the email genuine? Does this person exist? Is it really my friend or colleague that's sending me these messages?

What you should do to test if the email is genuine

To test whether an email is genuine, you should check two things:

1. Does the email reply
Email 5:
From: Susan

According to your offer for naphtha, if you still have stock, we can negotiate based on your price. Susan

If you're sending emails back and forth with a bot, you're probably using some sort of reply template. A human would never send an email back and forth using exactly the same template.

2. Is there any other information in the email that could be used to validate that it's really the person sending it?

To start with, you should look for:

This is a topic that I cover in more detail in my article on spotting bots.

The key here is that you can't just rely on one factor to validate whether an email is genuine. You have to combine multiple factors together. You have to ask yourself: How strong is each of these factors? How confident am I that this email is genuine? Am I still worried that it might be a

Hello Mr. Jones,                    We are looking to ship 1,100MT of shoes from Rotterdam to Boston. Can you confirm your earliest available sail date, and can you let me know if you have a regular schedule?                    Kind regards,                    Anne
Email 2:
Anne,                    We would be happy to help with your shipment. Our regular weekly sailing is on the 23rd of the month. This shipment will sail on the 25th of March. Please confirm your delivery address and let me know if you have any further questions.                    Best regards,                    Don

Anne wrote back:
Hi Don,                    Yes, I think that works for us. The final destination for the goods will be Boston, MA. We will be clearing the goods through Port Newark, NJ.                    Thank you for your help!                    Anne

Later on, a similar conversation:
<Email 1>:
Hi Don,                    I’m following up about the shipping to Boston, MA. I spoke with our customs broker who said they will need to ship from NJ. Can you let me know if that will be a problem?                    Thanks,                    Anne

<Email 2
Email 3:
Hi Anne,                    NJ is not a problem. The vessel leaves from Rotterdam, then stops in Houston and NJ, before going to Boston. The final destination for the cargo is Boston, and you will clear the cargo in Boston, so that is fine.                    Please let me know if you have any further questions.                    Don

I personally hate being in this kind of situation.
- Does it matter if you clear your cargo in NJ or Boston?
- Is the stop in Houston worth including in the quote? If we talk about ports-of-call, does it mean we are talking about trans-shipments?
- What does it mean when Don said "final destination for cargo" was Boston?
In this kind of case, the shipper has spoken with their customs broker. They have consulted their maritime lawyer. They know the procedures to follow. That is why they ask you if you can handle the
Email 4:

You will also be responsible for unloading the cargo, or arranging for that to be done.                    Please let me know if you have any further questions.                    Regards,                    Ed

 Dear Frank,                 Yes, there have been some modifications made to the vessel since it was built in 1995. The first modification was in 2010 when a new engine was installed. This new engine has increased the vessel’s cargo capacity to 7000MT and increased its efficiency. In 2017, the vessel underwent another modification in which its six layers were lined with waterproof cloth and epoxy. This modification has improved the vessel’s ability to carry cargo without leaking and increased its durability. We believe that these modifications have improved the vessel’s performance and made it a better choice for shipping iron ore.                    Regards,                    Scott

The way you are supposed to write a business email is completely different from the way a formal letter is written.
Business Emailing Etiquette:
Write business emails in a direct, concise and informal style
Maintain a formal, respectful tone
Address the recipient by name, never by using “Dear Mr.” or “Dear Ms.” or any such title
Always include a complimentary closing at the end of the email
Check spelling, grammar, punctuation and any errors in the content
Use appropriate salutations for various situations
Choose an appropriate email subject
Use an appropriate email signature
After writing the email, add a sender’s signature, which includes your name and contact details
Avoid

John’s first email to Sam:1. The 1st time, when there is no previous correspondence, you should always start with the sender’s name, followed by a comma and your own name and address. The whole point of the sender’s name is to emphasize the directness and friendliness of the e-mail.
2. Avoid first names in your introduction until you get to know the other party. In your subsequent emails, a simple “Hi Sam” will do.
3. The first and last paragraphs should always contain the same information as the cover letter you would send if this were a hard copy. This is done to provide clarity and ensure that the recipient

However, if you put the same information into a 'smartcard', suddenly it becomes very interesting. A Smartcard can contain information, documents, images, videos and even music. It can also include online links and information that can be downloaded from the Internet, as well as many other things. Smartcards can be sent as gifts
